ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Matrix properties, eigenvectors, svd
Matrices and how to use them to solve functions. Linear Combination and Transformation. Eigenvector and Eigenvalues.

I learned a lot of concepts of linear algebra such as eigenvalues & eigenvectors, QR Factorization, vector spaces, linear transformations. I also built on my existing knowledge of matrices and determinants.
I gained a solid understanding of linear algebra from this course!

Linear Algebra is an absolutely essential topic for everyone in Physics/Engineering/Computer Science/etc. I learnt how to calculate impossible-to-solve equations (linear or differential) with the elegance matrices provide. I improved my proficiency with computations as the course is really computation-based. I finally know what on earth the "eigen-stuff" that I hear all the time in physics is!
tones
Learned a lot about matrices, eigenvalues, bases

This course, as in the name, provides an overview of the field of linear algebra and its applications. Key concepts that were taught include matrix operations, inverses, determinants, eigenvalues/vectors, and single value decomposition.
Calculations related to matrices.

I learned concepts in linear algebra and practiced solving problems accurately. The course was also full of reminders that collaboration and assistance from others is often crucial for success, and that sometimes I am very lucky.
I learned important methods in linear algebra
I learned a lot about linear algebra -- I really started seeing Mathematics from a new angle through this class!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The psets are decent for learning the topic but use weird numbers for no reason

I withdrew from this course before the third and final midterm. Part of this is my own fault as I didn't keep up with the weeks and attempted to re-watch lectures instead of go to them live and ask questions. I also didn't find a study group (being off campus). But I also think this course is poorly organized and didn't prepare students well to be successful. The videos to watch before class were usually very long, and then lectures also went over. As someone who was able to easily engage with Math 120, I thought Math 222 was very confusing. Answers were never posted for PSETs, so you couldn't tell what you did wrong or right. TAs also couldn't check your answers to help you. In the beginning, study guides didn't have answers either. TAs and Peer Tutors were hit or miss. For people taking this course, I recommend following MIT Courseware, 3Blue1Brown, and Khan Academy (I learned about these resources too late), but I think their explanations were more clear on most topics.

Strenghts: The course material was relevant, the problem sets were reasonable and a good test of knowledge, having minimum cut offs was nice (for ex. 90%+ guarantees an A)
Weaknesses: The exams were unnecessarily time consuming given the time constraints. They weren't even hard, given how I knew how to solve everything. I could just never finish them. This was frustrating because the exams ended up becoming a test of how fast you can multiply matrices rather than how well you understand the concepts. In a world where matrices can just be multiplied using a calculator and understanding concepts is more important, the exams were not reasonable. Another weakness of the course was the extra credit problem set. There was no mention of an extra credit problem set in the syllabus. It was suddenly introduced in the last week of classes and made due during reading week. When many of us are juggling finals, it was a huge inconvenience to have a problem set due that is equivalent in weightage to a midterm, especially when we weren't told about it in advance and couldn't plan for it. Given the really high weightage of the problem set, anyone who didn't turn it in would suffer with a bad grade. Additionally, it was annoying how the last problem in this pset was a coding question. It is not necessary that people in a math class know how to code, so it didn't make sense to ask people to code when the course didn't teach anything about coding. I also didn't understand why problem set solutions and practice midterm solutions were never posted - this was a huge drawback for me.
The recorded lectures definitely helped by allowing us to learn at our own pace and time.

The videos took a horrendous amount of time to watch, given that 2 out of 3 professors often typed their notes before they recorded the video, so you needed to pause the video every 10 seconds to copy down the large amounts of text that would appear. The videos did not give enough detail or provide useful examples to apply to the problem sets or midterms. The notes were extremely poor preparation for the problem sets and midterms. I found the internet to be more useful for solving problems than the notes were.

Strengths: Interesting material, not harsh grading (a bit lenient in fact?), accessible Peer Tutors, fun textbook

Weaknesses: The professors are smart but dull (Taylor is an exception, she's fun). Even if Linear Algebra is quite interesting and applicable, I doubt the professors would have made me enjoy it one bit (Thanks Khan Academy for the amazing 144 videos!) The recorded lectures hardly focused on conceptualizing the lesson or motivating what we learned--they often gave "definitions", "claims" or dry "proofs" making it hard to understand let alone appreciate L.A. for first-timers (Taylor, again, is an exception). Of course, I qualified this with an "often" because there were some superior lectures with clear presentations (but this wasn't the norm). Another HUGE weakness is the fact that the profs. don't provide Practice Exams as they did in MATH 120. It's just weird and senseless to just give out, during exam season, "practice questions that do not parallel the exam's length or difficulty"! If it was possible in MATH 120, I don't see why it's impossible in MATH 222. Finally, Strang's textbook is great but I'd suggest a different version of his book ("Intro to Linear Algebra") as opposed to L.A. With Applications because the former has a LOT of solid practice problems and even clearer applications.

Weakness was organization -- I didn't have access to the other classes notes even though they were all available. Answer keys and exam review was not sent out until right a day or two before the exam. It felt like the content we would learn in class was disconnected from what we learned in the videos. A strength of the course could be the psets. They were pretty difficult, but were my main way of learning the material.

The biggest strength of this course was its use of pre-recorded content to teach the content, and then review and dive deep into this content in the lecture. This allowed for the students to pause and re-watch vital or difficult content, allowing for a greater understanding of the class. 

One of the biggest weaknesses of this course was its lack of content for exam review. I simply wish we had previous years' exams to study with, as going into the exam, we had no sense of how long / how many problems the exam would be.

The recorded lectures were thorough and time-consuming, especially since I wanted to take good notes on them; I often found myself slightly behind in catching up on video lectures. Watching the professor work through concepts and examples in live classes was helpful, even if I did not always have the opportunity to watch the corresponding video first.
The course was a good pace and I liked the three non-cumulative tests.
This class was very good!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Some of the lecture notes sucked
I liked the format with short pre-recorded videos and then practice questions in the virtual live lectures.
The flexibility provided by recorded lectures was very helpful.
The recorded lectures were an awful waste of time. They took forever and were not well made.
I think ease of access could be improved. Some notes were better than other classes, and given the whole course was online, I don't see why I couldn't have seen all the notes.
One of the biggest practices during the COVID-19 pandemic that benefited the course was the inclusion of pre-recorded videos before the live lecture.

During the covid semester, the class was taught online with prerecorded lectures each week. The 3 instructors took turns recording the videos which meant that every week there was a new lecture style and notation for the material. This was confusing. The in class lectures were very helpful and it was nice to have time to ask questions on the material and get more practice. The homeworks were challenging but manageable if you went to office hours. They did have some errors in the homeworks so hopefully those will be fixed by next semester.
The pre-recorded videos could sometimes feel tedious because they were very long sometimes. Overall, though, all content was helpful and introduced useful material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes its good to learn the basics of linear algebra
If it's a requirement.

Yes, I would. It is definitely easier than 225, so if you need a linear algebra course and would prefer the computational version, I recommend this course. The material is relevant and applicable, and as long as you're consistent with your work you'll get a good grade without too much struggle.
Yes! This course is a great introduction to linear algebra.
Absolutely not. The notes were terrible, the problem sets and midterms were not prepared for by the notes & classes, and the professors were not great.

Yes, if you need it for your major. I chose this over MATH 225 and I'm very satisfied with my choice. I would not have covered the breadth of info treated in MATH 222 had I opted for the former proof-based class (much more suited for math majors imo!) But I have a huge caveat: don't depend on the profs./class to learn the concepts. Watch the 144-video-playlist on Khan Academy over the summer/Winter Break and the short 3Blue1Brown L.A. playlist on YouTube--that will give you enough time to absorb the abstract and not-uncomplicated (sorry for the double negative) topics in Linear Algebra. Plus, you'll safely focus on doing practice problems during exam season as opposed to worrying about "getting this new hard concept." And if you attend Peer Tutor/Discussion Section sessions (which I recommend!), you'll not feel brain-dead as the TA/ULA/PT is trying to explain the class concepts (as some people used to feel, myself included, at times!). In a nutshell: Take it after you know it--if you need it.

I would not recommend this to another student if possible. I didn't have a lot of fun, and the whole class just felt like I was grinding out psets. Content was much easier to learn from outside videos.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially a student interests in the applications of linear algebra or the fields of economics, computer science and machine learning, etc. However, with the recent change in the math sequence and inclusion of another linear algebra course, I am unsure which to recommend.
Yes, good for applications of linear algebra.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants a basic understanding of popular linear algebra methods with no proofs.
Yes, it is a very useful class that is applicable in many fields.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Slides
live virtual lecture and recorded lectures
Office Hours and Discussion Sections
I would usually just watch the recorded lectures. I wasn't able to make it to the live virtual lectures, so I would watch those recorded too.
Recorded lecture, recorded sections.
This class had around 5 20+ minute recorded lectures that we had to watch each week for content. Then, during the scheduled times, the professor would go through problems related to the new content.
Also used live virtual lectures 2x a week where we were supposed to watch the videos before each class.
live virtual lecture, office hours
Discussion Sections
In addition to virtual class sessions, the course also heavily revolved around recorded video lectures.
there was live lecture and recorded lectures
We also had pre-class pre-recorded videos. The lectures were also recorded.
